name: NEGOTIATIONS

values.comments:
Legal Studies 806, Negotiations and Conflict Resolution, examines the art and science of negotiation, with additional emphasis on conflict resolution. Students will engage in a number of simulated negotiations ranging from simple one-issue transactions to multi-party joint ventures. Through these exercises and associated readings, students explore the basic theoretical models of bargaining and have an opportunity to test and improve their negotiation skills. 
	One student “highly” recommended the course to others, and another said “overall, the class was good.” Specifically mentioned were the guest lectures and in-class negotiations, which students found interesting. However some students thought the class could use more structure, and one student thought that they “could have gotten more out of lecture if we had debriefed the exercises the week after they did them.”
	Professor Brandt received predominantly positive reviews. One student mentioned that Professor Brandt “turned way too much into personal story-telling time,” and sometimes “didn’t keep the course on track,” but most students agreed that Professor Brandt “is a professor that cares about his students and demonstrates passion in his negotiation stories and lessons.”
	This is an MBA course and consists of lecture, class discussion, simulation/role play, and video demonstrations. The required materials are a textbook and course pack. Auditors for this course need permission.

LGST 806 examines the art and science of negotiation, with additional emphasis on conflict resolution. Students engage in a number of simulated negotiations ranging from simple one-issue transactions to multi-party joint ventures. Through these exercises and associated readings, students explore the basic theoretical models of bargaining and have an opportunity to test and improve their negotiation skills. The course is cross-listed with MGMT 691 and OPIM 691.  The format is lecture, class discussion, simulation/role play, and video demonstrations.  The class materials include a textbook and course pack.
Most students gained “really useful and practical negotiating tools” from LGST 806, and one suggested that taking it was a “practical real world experience that every Wharton students should [have].”  Many students felt that the frameworks and “easily-digestible set of tools presented” would serve them well moving forward, and they appreciated that the “course [offered] plenty of opportunities to practice.”  In particular, they felt that the “cases every week [were] really helpful to practice and understand how people react in negotiations.”
A few students highlighted that Professor Diamond is “obviously incredibly successful, accomplished, and knowledgeable in the field.”  Several appreciated the insights he offered during case debriefs, and a few mentioned that his teaching style was “abrasive but very effective.”  
Students’ did not find the workload or difficulty of the course to be noteworthy, but several complained about “the tardiness of the feedback on the assignments.”  LGST 806 is an MBA course.
